columns.text: In this exercise, we are asked to assess the dilution.

Let us first identify the given amounts in the problem: 


| | Amount$\hspace{5pt}$| 
|:--|--:| 
|Shares outstanding| 6 million|
|Share price|$64.00| 
|Book value per share |$19.00|
|Net income| $11.5 million|
|Cost of new facility | $30 million|
|Increase net income |$675,000.00|

## A. 
First, let us determine the number of shares the company will sell. This is computed by dividing the cost of the new facility by the share price. As an illustration, here's what it looks like: 

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Number of shares to sell}&=\dfrac{\text{Cost of new facility}}{\text{Share price}}\\[10pt]
&=\dfrac{\text{\$30 million}}{\text{\$64.00}}\\[10pt]
&={\textbf{468,750}}
\end{aligned}$$ 

**The company will sell 468,750 additional shares.**

Now, let us calculate the new book value per share. The current book value per share is multiplied by the number of shares outstanding to obtain at this amount. We will also multiply the share price by the number of new shares the company will sell.

Both amounts will be added and divided by the total number of shares after offering. As an illustration, here is what it looks like: 
$$\begin{aligned}
\text{New book value per share}&=\dfrac{\text{(6,000,000 $\times$ \$19.00) + (468,750 $\times$ \$64.00)}}{\text{6,000,000 + 468,750}}\\[10pt]

&={\textbf{\$22.26}}
\end{aligned}$$ 

**The new book value per share amounts to $22.26.**

To compute the current price-earnings ratio, we need first to compute the current EPS of the company. This is computed as follows: 

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Current EPS}&=\dfrac{\text{Net income}}{\text{Shares outstanding}}\\[10pt]
&=\dfrac{\text{\$11.5 million}}{\text{6 million}}\\[10pt]
&={\textbf{\$1.92}}
\end{aligned}$$ 

**The current EPS of the company is $1.92 per share.**

Next, let us compute the current price-earnings ratio since the problem noted that the price-earnings ratio will be constant. This is computed as follows: 

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Current price-earnings ratio}&=\dfrac{\text{Share price}}{\text{Current EPS}}\\[10pt]
&=\dfrac{\text{\$64.00}}{\text{\$1.92}}\\[10pt]
&={\textbf{\$33.33}}
\end{aligned}$$ 

**The company's current price-earnings ratio amounts to $33.33 per share.**

Then, let us compute the new EPS of the company. This is computed by adding the increase in the net income to the current net income and dividing the result by the total number of shares after offering. This is computed as follows: 
$$\begin{aligned}
\text{New EPS}&=\dfrac{\text{Net income + Increase in net income}}{\text{Total number shares after offering}}\\[10pt]
&=\dfrac{\text{\$11.5 million + \$675,000.00}}{\text{6,000,000 + 468,750}}\\[10pt]

&={\textbf{\$1.88}}
\end{aligned}$$ 

**If the net income increases, the new EPS will be $1.88 per share.**

Now, assuming the price-earnings ratio remains constant, the new share price will result from multiplying the current price-earnings ratio that we have computed from step 6 and the new EPS of the company that we have computed from step 7. As an illustration, here's what it looks like: 

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Share price}&={\text{Current price-earnings ratio $\times$ New EPS}}\\
&={\text{\$33.33 $\times$ \$1.88}}\\
&={\textbf{\$62.66}}
\end{aligned}$$ 

**The new share price of the company amounts to $62.66.**

Then, let us compute the new market-to-book ratio. This is computed by dividing the new share price by the current market-to-book ratio. This is computed as follows: 

 $$\begin{aligned}
\text{Share price}&=\dfrac{\text{New share price}}{\text{ Book value per share}}\\[10pt]
&=\dfrac{\text{\$62.66}}{\text{\$19.00}}\\[10pt]
&={\textbf{3.30}}
\end{aligned}$$ 

**The new market-to-book ratio is 3.30.**

## B. 

Now, let us compute the new net income for the company have to be for the stock price to remain unchanged. This is computed by multiplying the new number of shares by the current EPS that we have computed in step 5. As an illustration, here's what it looks like: 

 $$\begin{aligned}
\text{New net income}&={\text{New number of shares $\times$ Current EPS }}\\
&={\text{6,468,750 $\times$ \$1.92 }}\\
&={\textbf{\$12,420,000.00}}
\end{aligned}$$ 

**The new net income of the company for the stock price to remain unchanged is $12,420,000.00.**
